titlepage.subtitle: Finding Aid
titlepage.author: Joel Tansey
titlepage.sponsor: Encoding funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Alfred Vance Churchill Papers
did.abstract: Professor of Fine Arts. Contains biographical material, correspondence, material related to museum and art collecting, publications, and teaching materials.

bioghist.p: Alfred Vance Churchill was born on August 14, 1864 in Oberlin, Ohio. He was the son of Charles Henry Churchill, a professor at Oberlin College and his second wife, Henrietta Vance Churchill. Alfred was the second child of Henrietta Vance Churchill, and was the sixth of Charles Henry Churchill's nine children. After studies at Oberlin, Alfred studied art in Berlin, Leipzig, and Paris from 1887-1890. He married Marie Marschall in 1890. Their son Louis Nelson Churchill was born in 1897. In 1892 Churchill directed the art department at Iowa College, Grinnell, Iowa. From 1893-1897, he taught art in the High and Normal Schools of St. Louis, Missouri. In 1897, he was made professor of art and Director of the Department of Fine Arts at Teachers College, Columbia University. He received the degree of Master of Arts from Oberlin College in 1898. Columbia University dismissed Churchill in 1904, but gave him a grant to study and paint in Paris 1904-1906. Smith College hired him in 1905 as the first resident professor in the appreciation and history of art. During his years at Smith, he expanded the Smith College Art Museum into one of the outstanding collections in the United States. A noted art critic, lecturer as well as a teacher and painter (whose work appeared in the Armory Show in Chicago in 1913), he influenced the standards of art teaching, especially as vice-president of the College Art Association. After 27 years of service to Smith, Churchill retired in 1932, staying in Northampton, Massachusetts, and devoting himself to painting and writing. He died on December 29, 1949.

scopecontent.p: There is copious correspondence with important art collectors and figures in the history of Smith College, as well as other educational institutions such as Columbia University. Researchers interested in Oberlin College, family history and the social history of the Midwestern U.S. will find the manuscripts and typescripts of his unpublished book Midwestern of interest. Genealogists will find some mention and dating of family names coming out of New England such as Franklin and Churchill. Art historians will be interested to note Churchill's writings and lectures on the teaching of art, and his role in developing an American taste for French Romantic painters.

arrangement.p: This collection is organized into four series:
There is some overlap in categories, but in keeping with the "respect des fonds," it was thought best to retain where possible the arrangement of certain folders which Churchill himself devised.

accessrestrict.p: The papers are open for research according to the regulations of the Smith College Archives without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. Permission to publish material from the documents must be requested from the Smith College Archives. Smith College owns copyright to any published material relating to college events and activities. Provenance and copyright ownership of other materials is unknown and researchers are responsible for determining any question of copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
Alfred Vance Churchill Papers, Box #, Smith College Archives.

acqinfo.p: Alfred Vance Churchill donated letters, photographs, poems, etc. from his own papers in 1941. Later in the same year he donated more files for his biographical record. Two letters written to the Smith College Archivist in 1941 or 1942 substantiate this as the year of donation, although nothing precludes the possibility of donations at an earlier date. On April 26, 1966, Mrs. Bernard A. Churchill [daughter-in-law] donated on behalf of Mrs. A. V. Churchill, a "MS of Oberlin book-typescript and carbon," written by Alfred Vance Churchill, which corresponds to the folders titled "Midwestern."

did.unittitle: Series I. Biographical Material 1828-1942

scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, news clippings, chronologies, obituary, and materials regarding retirement from Smith College and departure from Columbia University. This series also contains family history documents, including photographs, correspondence, and assorted other materials.

did.unittitle: Letters to Smith College Archives. 1941-42
Biographical materials and chronology. Includes obituary.

Retirement from Smith College. (Includes letters from Stephan Bourgeois, Gordon B. Washburn, J. B. Neumann, Frank Jewett Mather, Daniel Catton Rich, Walter Pach, W. R. Valentiner, Edward Alden Jewell) 1931-35
Columbia Teachers College. (Includes letters from John Dewey and James E. Russell) 1897-1939

Photographs: Alfred Vance Churchill and family. (Includes Charles Henry Churchill and sister Lucretia Churchill in 1842, Henrietta Vance Churchill, Polly Franklin Churchill, Emilie von Zulich 1828, David Carroll Churchill) 1828-1932, undated
Genealogy materials. (Includes letters from Mrs. William A. Whitney and Benjamin E. Franklin) 1936, undated
Genealogy book: The Churchills of Oberlin 1965

Genealogical materials: Henrietta Beach Vance [grandmother]. (Includes materials about and letters of Henrietta Beach Vance to Alfred and Marie Churchill, materials related to the Vance family in Lagrange County, and to Lewis Nelson Churchill) 1894-1936
Will and account book of Henrietta Beach Vance [grandmother]. 1886-1901
Obituaries of Henrietta Vance Churchill [mother]. 1898-99
Letters and writings of Henrietta Vance Churchill [mother]. 1858, 1892-93
Letters of Charles Henry Churchill [father] to Alfred and Marie Churchill 1890-1904
Letters to Charles Henry Churchill from family. (Includes photograph and postcard from Lyme, New Hampshire) 1838-43, undated
Materials on Charles Henry Churchill [father]. 1872-1936
Letters from brothers and sisters. 1898-1941, undated
Letters to family from Berlin. 1888-90
Family letter. 1895
Family letter about Edward [brother]. 1933-34
Series II. General and Professional Correspondence 1889-1942

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence relating to Churchill's research and and career at Smith College.

did.unittitle: General correspondence. 1901-42
Letters from Laurence Binyon 1914-34
Correspondence with Marion LeRoy Burton 1914-17
Letters from Charles Lang Freer 1913-16
Letters to Grace Gilfillan 1901-04
Correspondence with Laurenus Clark Seelye 1905-15
Correspondence with Dwight William Tryon 1912-25
Letters from Alice B. Tryon 1926, undated
Letters from Hugh Walpole 1922-26
Letters from Henry C. White 1929
Series III. Museum and Art Collecting Materials 1905-1941

scopecontent.p: This series includes materials related to museum exhibitions and art collecting, and Churchill's own art work.

did.unittitle: Gericault exhibit: brochure and correspondence 1929-36
Booklet on art collecting: "Building a Collection" Full title: Building a Collection: Notes on the Work of Alfred Vance Churchill. Published by the American Association of University Women 1937?
Catalogues of the Smith College Museum of Art. One of the two copies is annotated by Churchill. 1937
Materials on Churchill's art and exhibits. Includes news clippings, brochure and correspondence. 1905-50, undated
Silhouettes of Smith College presidents. Includes correspondence. 1938-39
Series IV. Publications and Teaching Materials 1900-1948

scopecontent.p: This series includes professional publications, course syllabi, lecture notes, speeches on art education, and transcripts of Churchill's book Midwestern.

did.unittitle: Prints used for courses Art 13 & 14 undated
Lecture notes and outlines for art history. Materials are printed, handwritten, or typed. 1917-18, undated
Materials on teaching art. Includes syllabi, correspondence. 1900-41
Speeches and materials on art in education 1902-30, undated
Article: "The Meaning and Aim of Art in Education" 1904
Article: "Art in the College Course" 1915

Pamphlet: "Italian Painters of the Renaissance" 1914
Article: "Picasso's Failure" 1925
Article: "On Cezanne" 1932
Typescript: translations of German songs 1941-48
Book: Golden Songs. Two copies, one annotated. 1947
Carbon typescript bound: "The Thirteenth Century" undated
Manuscript: poems 1904, undated
Background materials for Midwestern 1902-40
Correspondence regarding families of Oberlin, Ohio.
Background materials for Midwestern 1935-38
Background materials for Midwestern. This folder was also arranged by Churchill himself. 1935-38
Manuscript of Midwestern, first folder undated

Manuscript of Midwestern, fourth folder undated
